46:59 Caption: Well, it hasn't been the most exciting game in the world but there has been some nice football on display. We hope that the second period will bring more action. We are witnessing quite a balanced game with both teams struggling to prevail. Long balls and crosses are the strongest weapons of the home team, while their opponents favour possession football.

48:04 Caption: That's all for today as the game is over.
48:59 Caption: We can only hope that the managers will be able to motivate the players and spark them into life in the next games. The football on offer today has been disappointing. Neither of the teams had any obvious superiority in this game. Long balls and crosses were the main weapons of the home team. The away team tried to find the weakness in the opposition's defence especially with rapid counter-attacks.
    

    #######TASK 
    Provide a factually correct and detailed textual description of the game compiled from the information presented above from different sources, in more than 1000 words.
            "Cap:": represents the captions published in the online portal usually within 30 seconds of the event.
            "E:" represents events recorded exactly after the event happened.
    Don't mention sources of information like commentators or captions, write as if you saw them live.
summary:
In a highly competitive and riveting match at the Stadio Renzo Barbera, Palermo took on AC Milan in an engaging fixture that kept fans on the edge of their seats from start to finish. The game, resplendent with tension and packed with significant moments, concluded with a 2-1 victory in favour of AC Milan.

The first half kicked off with Palermo initiating the proceedings. However, an initial bout of misplaced passes and nervousness seemed to beset the teams, resulting in several interruptions. Early on, just after the commencement, the ball went out of play, drawing a throw-in for AC Milan. However, there was a quick series of back-and-forth plays, peppered with fouls, particularly by Palermo, leading to several free-kicks granted to AC Milan within the first ten minutes.

Palermo's Thiago Rangel Cionek seemed a little over-zealous with his challenges, committing a notable foul at around ten minutes, a move that positioned AC Milan with a free-kick from a dangerous spot. AC Milan failed to capitalize on this chance as Giacomo Bonaventura fired high over the crossbar, much to the relief of Palermo’s supporters. 

As short bursts of action ensued, the tempo of the game was slightly erratic but started to build up. Another moment arrived with Bonaventura again driving forward, tricking his way past defenders into the penalty box, only to drag his shot narrowly wide of the right post, showing an early sign of his influence on the game.

The breakthrough came in the 14th minute when Suso struck a remarkable goal for AC Milan. It was a piece of individual brilliance as he smashed the ball from medium range into the left post, igniting celebrations among the away supporters. Palermo then quickly resumed the game but faced an uphill battle, challenged to find an equalizer.

Palermo managed to get some footing in the game a little later, resulting in Carlos Embalo having a shot on target from a free-kick. AC Milan's goalkeeper, Gianluigi Donnarumma, showcased his skills and made an excellent save, maintaining Milan’s slender lead.

The game fell into a pattern with frequent fouls and stoppages, disrupting the flow. Palermo couldn't fully capitalize on several corner opportunities that could have shifted the momentum. Thiago Rangel Cionek continued to look menacing on set-pieces but unfortunately directed his headers off-target.

AC Milan enjoyed several attacks as the first half closed down, and a notable save from Josip Posavec stood out when he wonderfully tipped Carlos Bacca’s threatening shot away. Right before the half-time whistle, Mattia De Sciglio received a yellow card for his behaviour, adding to the cautious tension on the field.

As the game approached the break, both teams struggled to maintain prolonged possession, often resorting to long balls and crosses without much efficacy. The half-time referee's whistle ended a low-tempo and somewhat scrappy first half with AC Milan holding a slim 1-0 lead.

The second half started much like the first, with some initial jitters leading to fouls and slow play. Palermo showed early aggression, and within the first ten minutes, they had already committed a handful of fouls, a sign of their determination to overturn the deficit. Thiago Rangel Cionek, who had been consistently involved, once again found himself on the wrong end of the referee's whistle for a careless challenge.

Palermo kept pushing forward, looking for the equalizer. Carlos Embalo unleashed a decent shot towards the right post, but once again Donnarumma was up to the task, maintaining Milan’s advantage with a fine save.

Roberto De Zerbi, Palermo’s manager, decided to shake things up and made substitutions bringing on Alessandro Diamanti for Roland Sallai and Simone Lo Faso for Carlos Embalo around the 65th minute mark. This shifted Palermo’s tactics slightly, making them more proactive in their pressing and attacking approaches.

However, AC Milan also introduced fresh legs, replacing Mario Pasalic with Matias Fernandez, hoping to maintain their midfield control and combat the renewed Palermo vigour. Midway through the second half, the hosts broke through. Ilija Nestorovski received a delightful pass inside the box and demonstrated clinical finishing, driving the ball low into the middle of the goal to draw Palermo level at 1-1.

As the game entered its final quarter, the atmosphere was electric, with both sets of fans urging their teams forward. AC Milan responded almost immediately. A string of corners kept the pressure on Palermo's defence. Giacomo Bonaventura was particularly influential in these set-pieces, delivering dangerous crosses into the box.

One of Milan’s corners led to chaos in the penalty area, and Gianluca Lapadula pounced on a loose ball inside the box, decisively beating the goalkeeper with a shot into the bottom left corner to make it 2-1 to AC Milan, around the 80th minute. It was a moment of composure amidst the frenzy and ultimately sealed the fate of the match.

Palermo, now trailing, tried heavily to mount a comeback in the dying minutes of the game but couldn't carve out clear-cut chances against a resolute Milan defence. A couple of off-target shots and blocked attempts summed up their desperate yet futile efforts as the clock ticked away.

Further disruptions, a sprinkling of fouls and substitutions characterised the closing stages. AC Milan showed composure in defence and sought to control the tempo, frustrating Palermo’s advances. Thiago Rangel Cionek, already booked, exhibited continued aggression but couldn't alter the outcome. 

As the final whistle blew, AC Milan emerged victorious by a narrow margin. The game, despite being contended and punctuated with fouls, showcased moments of individual brilliance. The tactical tweaks throughout the match and fresh legs brought on made significant impacts on the dynamic of the match. Gianluca Lapadula's opportunistic finish stood out as the decisive moment in a contest that ultimately saw AC Milan maintain their advantage and secure all three points. 

This match serves as a testament to AC Milan’s resilience, strategic discipline and individual flair against a determined Palermo side keen to challenge till the very end. However, the distinct playstyle differences were apparent. Palermo relied predominantly on long balls and set-pieces, whereas AC Milan favoured creating and exploiting spaces through possession, ultimately vindicating this approach through their decisive second goal. As both teams look ahead, the managers will surely reflect on this balanced yet hard-fought encounter, aiming for more cohesive and sharpened performances in their subsequent games.
